Hey there!  Lauren here.  I LOVE Avatar: The Last Airbender and I recommend it to anyone who is looking for something new and exciting to watch.  It's dramatic, suspenseful and very enjoyable to watch.  It's full of adventure as well.

In a time when the world is divided into four nations:  Water tribes, earth kingdoms, fire nation and air nomads, it seems peaceful.  But that all changes when the greedy and power hungry fire nation starts a war with the other three nations.  The world's only hope is the Avatar, a boy who can master the bending disciplines of all four elements.  But he hasn't been seen for a hundred years.  It's not until a waterbender named Katara and her annoying older brother, Sokka, free Aang from an iceburg, do they uncover the world's last hope.  Now it's up to Aang to learn all four bending disciplines in order to end the war and bring balance back to the world.  With the help of Katara and Sokka, Aang will learn a lot more than the bending arts. He will learn what true friendship is.

Water, earth, fire air.

Long ago, the four nations lived together in harmony

Then everything changed when the fire nation attacked

Only the Avatar, master of all four elements could stop them

But when the world needed him most, he vanished

A hundred years passed and my brother and I discovered the new Avatar.  An airbender named Aang.  And although his airbending skills are great, he has a lot to learn before he's ready to save anyone

But I believe, Aang can save the world

Join Katara, her annoying brother, Sokka and their friend, Aang, as they make their way to the North Pole in search of a waterbending teacher for Katara.  Also, As the Avatar, Aang must master all four elements in order to defeat the fire lord and restore balance to the world.

I've been watching this show for nine months now and I LOVE it.  Katara is my favorite character and I believe Mae Whitman portrays her really well.  I LOVE this show and I can't wait till it comes to DVD.  Like Katara, my element is also water.  I identify with Katara the most.

May the power of water, earth, fire and air be with everyone always.

At First when I would see commercials for this show I rolled my eyes and thought - "oh no!  more anime?!"  I consider myself more in the 'older' generation of Nickelodeon viewers - Rocko's Modern Life, Doug, etc, even though I do enjoy Spongebob, Danny Phantom, and Fairly odd Parents, so I didn't really want to give this show a chance - I thought Nickelodeon was just doing the 'popular anime' thing...

Eventually I came around and watched an Episode of Avatar, and I'm so glad I did!  This show is done extremely well, with more research, time, and effort put in to it than any other I have seen!  It's the kind of show that you really get into - one of those 'escapist' type shows where you forget about everything else, and feel like you are in Aang's world.  I even feel like I want to 'bend' sometimes...well, actually, I feel like this ALL the time!

The story is amazing, and so well thought out.  The characters are well developed, especially one of my favorites: Prince Zuko.  At first, he is depicted as a bratty teen with a bad temper - nothing more than another 'bad guy.'  You soon begin to discover more about his persona, and how he came to be, and you actually start to feel for him.

There is a good mix of humor, action, and heart felt-emotion with this show.  Nick does a good job - in a way - of 'spoofing' anime style drawing, while respecting it.  This is especially evident with the facial expressions used on the characters.

I can't say enough about this show!  I've seen every episode, and can't wait for the new one's to come out.  I'll definitely be buying this DVD.  Give it a chance sometime, I'm really glad I did!

Season 2 of ATLA is even better than Book 1: Water; not that the first season was bad (it was mind-blowingly good) but thanks to Book 2, we get introduced to a plethora of some amazing new characters who's personalities are truly great.
The story continues strong. Rather than take some bizarre unnecessary plummet after an exceptional beginning, Book 2 comes in with a bang and keeps that initial momentum on a constant rise. With new cast members, new techniques, new scenery, and insight on the internal struggles of the gang and the new characters, the audience remains thoroughly entertained by this engrossing next chapter.
You fall in love with the new players, and even more so with the original gang as you watch them go through the roller coaster fate has put them on; as well as anxious for their futures. In other words, prepare to become seriously fandom obsessed. Because yes, the new season is just that good.
Onward (in a more serious voice! ->) The wonderful thing about this season is that you develop so much hope for things to come through foreshadows, the plot, the entire cast, and personalities you're so fond of. Rather than breeze through in the want to just "get it over with" you want to really take it in and marinate on every episode. Between life lessons, battles, and twists, this season brings a lot to the table (or should I say Pi Sho table?? Ha ha get it?! It's okay Sokka would)
Book 2: Earth is exactly like the element it's named after: strong, powerful, and enthralling.

This is easily the best children's show!  It teaches kids about honor, loyalty, courage, love, kindness, justice, inner strength.  There are no stupid, fashion-frenzied girls, no situations that are inappropriate for little kids to see, no gore, no bad language.  This is a show that you can sit down and watch with your kids because it is so engaging.  The characters do not always make the right decisions, but they learn (the right) lessons.  Disrespect, greed, selfishness, vanity, cowardice, dishonesty, pride are all dealt with as wrong, not understandable, or acceptable in certain situations...
The protagonists are all children from age 10-16, and they act like it.  But they learn to survive, and pursue good in a very hostile and difficult world.  Yet, despite the serious topics and situations, there is light-hearted humor that keeps it from being depressing.  And there are certainly tear-jerker parts, but it's not cheap sensationalism and emotional garbage that does it (like Pokmon), it's true loss, real suffering, self-sacrifice, glory, reunion joy, and the vindication of right.

Okay, sense there are tons and tons of reviews for this series that give it endless praise, I will try and keep it brief when I tell you about my extreme love for the series. First of all, the plot in this story is great. I'm not going to be saying any spoilers in this review about the show, but can I just say... the plot is pretty impressive. It's complex, interesting and pretty easy to follow at the same time. Also, there's not many plot holes at all, which is always good. Second of all, the music in the show is great as well. Throughout the series, we often hear enchanting drum melodies playing in the background or at the end credits. The drum beats were amazing and well put together, just like all of the other music in the show. Next, we have to talk about the characters. Once again, I have to say that the character development and originality here is also great. In the show, we have deeper, more interesting characters that are well rounded and thought out. So, basically what I'm trying to say is, the characters in Avatar aren't just your stereotypical, 2 dimensional teenagers that you see in almost every other movie. They are much more interesting (and fun) to watch than that. Next, we of course have to talk about the art and animation in the show. Oh gosh- the animation and art is so good! Throughout the entire series, we have had complex, detailed backgrounds, nicely drawn characters and great animation. What more can you have than that? Oh yeah, there actually is one more thing that you can have, and that thing is great voice actors! Yep, the voice actors in this show are great, too. Just to list off a couple voice actors that worked on the show, we have Azula's voice actor as Grey Griffin, (The gal who voiced Daphne in Scooby-Doo) and Fire Lord Ozai, who is voiced by Mark Hamill. (Yes- the Mark Hamill from Star Wars).
So there you have it, folks! Pretty much every good aspect a show needs to have- Avatar has! This show is just downright phenomenal, and I would recommend it to any child or adult alike.

I'm writing this after revisiting the series and watching it a second time.  The second season of Avatar: The Last Airbender is incredibly affecting.  The first time I pushed through this series, I mostly found myself impressed by the fight scenes and animation style.  This last go-round, however, I find myself regretting the fact that I did not pay more attention to the characters and the writing.
  I recall liking the Zuko and Iroh sections of the show the first time, but this latest viewing has me appreciating Iroh even more.  There was a scene with Iroh in Season Two that had me in tears.  (For the record, I consider myself to be jaded, rolling my eyes at even live-action drama scenes.)  And, of course, this season includes the introduction of Toph (which, by the way, is an EXCELLENT episode!), the exploration of past Avatar lives, and the grand city of Ba Sing Se.  All of these are reasons enough to pay special attention to this show's second season.  The real treasure of Book 2, though, is in the characters and how they are handled throughout.
  So... if you find yourself on the fence about watching Book Two after being less than impressed with Book One, I encourage you to at least stay with Aang and the crew until they get to Ba Sing Se.  If you're still not convinced that this series is must-watch television, maybe you should quit television altogether?

I don't even know how to review this... I'm over 40, and while I first found this series back when my step-daughter was 9 and looking for an exciting fantasy series upholding values of compassion and friendship, with strong female characters and lots of magic...  I was immediately hooked myself.  So was my husband! This series is all of the above, but also just an awesome, rollicking good tale.  In the first season it stuck very close to that sort Joseph Campbellian, Star Warsian, epic journey storytelling strategy (which I loved, Loved LOVED), but in Season 2 it began to diverge just slightly and became more unique, more unexpected and more memorable.  It was maybe a little less satisfying, because of that.  I think I've been trained to expect the storytelling archetypes, so I guess I missed some of those elements. Of course, they still gave us the bittersweet, season-ending cliffhanger a la Empire Strikes Back!
In the end, Season 2 is the season I remember best, except for the finale of Season 1.  Just can't recommend it highly enough, regardless of age.

The entire Avatar series is one of the best television shows marketed to young adults that I've ever seen.  Unlike most people, I didn't watch it when it was new (in fact, I've only just watched it in the last month), nor was I young enough to be in the intended demographic when it was new.  However, it is fortunate that the intended demographic is just that.  Intended.  Not limited to, by any means.

Most shows marketed to children or young adults are done so because the show is purposely designed with just enough depth to draw them in, and then enough flashing colors, sounds, and silliness that they stick around and watch more.  Avatar is far more than that (although, that's not to say that it isn't a vibrantly colored and funny experience as well).

Through the viewer's shared journeys with Aang, Katara, Sokka, Toph, Iroh, and even the cast-out Prince Zuko, they're taught a myriad of important life lessons that I truly believe everyone, adults included (perhaps especially), need to learn.  Even the ones that they already know are not only beneficial when seen from a new point of view, but they're genuinely good, clean fun when experienced through the adventures of Aang and company.

I can not recommend this show more for viewers of any age.

It is a really long season. But it is enjoyable to see so much of the world. I also enjoyed watching these characters evolve throughout this season. Some of the episodes were fillers, but even a few of the fillers helped develop the characters and made me care for them more.

Season 2 was still good, but unfortunately I felt it was quite a bit worse than season 1.
Spoilers below.

What I liked:
- A lot of focus on Iroh, one of my favorite characters ever
- Nice story arc for Appa, another awesome character
- Toph was a great new addition to the cast.
- Introduction of Blue firebending
- Flashbacks in episode Zuko Alone are fantastic
- Nice continuity, return of old characters
- Continued humor, though unfortunately less than season 1.
- Art is still good.

What I didn't like:
- I thought Zuko was lame in the previous season, but that was nothing compared to how lame he is in this season. In season 2 he doesn't even try to attack the Avatar or do much of anything, really.  He just wanders around in a "morally conflicted" state doing nothing except ignoring the wise words of Iroh.  I was hoping this would all be building up to a character change, but the finale just reinforced his incredible stubbornness and stupidity. A real letdown.

- Too much time in Ba Sing Se.  It's a great location and I'm glad we spent time there, but spending 8 episodes there? Just too much.  This series works best when the heroes are traveling together.

- Nonexistent presence of the Fire Nation.  In season one the gang was constantly fighting massive Fire Nation armies.  This season, they face a major fire nation army exactly once.

- Lame adversaries.  Instead of the Fire Nation military, this season the main enemies are three Fire Nation girls. One holds back because she has a crush on Sokka, one is too pampered and lazy to do much of anything. The last, Azula, is more formidable, but she only pops up to fight from time to time and can be beaten in combat fairly easily. Her motivation is totally unclear, it's also unclear why almost no one ever tries to double-cross her. Her plans seem complex but are actually pretty simple, her main power seems to be convincing others to do her bidding. How she manages to do this is pretty mystifying, the series want us to believe people follow her just because she can give a good speech (Huh?).  Unlike others, I didn't find her to be a very compelling villain, especially acting all by herself without any army.

- Despite spending such a long time in Ba Sing Se, we never get a clear account of what happened to Iroh and his son there, which was the one burning question I had about the place.  We can guess of course, but this seems like such a missed opportunity.

- A surprisingly tired and unexciting tale of a puppet head of state and government conspiracy.  This is supposed to be the climax of the season but falls super flat.

- Big plot holes that are impossible to overlook:

  * The gang decides not to march on the Fire Nation since Aang's avatar state only activates when he is in true distress, they can't force it to activate, and he's too weak to win without using it.  Um, what?  Wouldn't being attacked by a bunch of firebenders be enough to cause him distress?

 * The gang goes through a lot of trouble to find King Bumi, only to have him give a very lame excuse that he wants to remain locked up to gain control from the inside.  The gang accepts this, lets him go, and we don't hear from him again.  Um, what?

 * Waterbenders in the swamp can bend plants, since they are mostly water?  Um, what?  So why can't waterbenders bend people, since people are mostly water?

 * There's a massive spire of an ancient library just sticking out of the sand, and no one knows about it, even the intrepid archaeologist?  And this spire is kept totally unguarded, despite the librarian wanting no one to enter?  And when our gang does arrive, he lets them through even though he knows they are lying, and then gets so mad when he gets confirmation of their deception that he destroys the whole thing?  Um, what?

 * Earthbenders can bend metal? Even though it was explicitly stated in previous episodes that they cannot? Um, what?

Despite having some good episodes and focusing on some great characters (Iroh), this season seem wandering and unfocused.  It almost seems as if the writers were struggling to come up with enough material.  3.5/5, I'll round down to counter the positive reviews.  Hope season 3 is a lot better.

This review speaks to the streamed version of this show, and less to the show itself, which is really awesome. For some bizarre reason, the decision was made to send interlaced frames instead of progressive ones, causing annoying visual artifacts that are horribly distracting, especially if you've already seen this show without them. Interlaced frames were designed for older televisions, which, sadly, have seen their time come and go. Even owners of the vaunted Sony Trinitrons, like myself, will admit that a progressive frame is far superior when displayed on a progressive screen, like most TVs today are. It hobbles this and many other fine programs, and when progressive sources are available, it's astonishing that Amazon missed this crucial step, being at heart a technology-driven company. Disappointing, but still, very worth watching, especially if you don't mind watching it through Levelor blinds.

Avatar is a wonderful show for two reasons.

One, it has demonstrated that Western animation has finally reached the level of depth, character development, and voice talent to rival other markets.

Two, it has a wonderful range of character types, points of representation (most notably for gender roles and people of color, with a main cast with racial traits and cultures based on non-white cultures).  This level of inclusion is rarely seen, and it is never a gimmick - never representation for represenation's sake.  Much of this show involves a culturally varied cast exploring a culturally dynamic world and directly interacting with the people, governments, and cultures they encounter.

And for the other things, art direction, music, etc. it remains at the highest quality.

This episode had quite a few subplots running through it that made it a good episode.  The episode kicks off with the kids settling in to get some rest and Toph and "Sugarqueen" having a spat.  The inherent problem is that Katara is a serious alpha female, control freak.  Aang is in love with her, so he would let her trample over him all day long (and she does) and Sokka has put up with it since he was a kid and he can work around it or just put up with it.  Toph on the other hand looks at her and doesn't play into her mother hen routine.  In some ways Katara is right, but frankly she's wrong on the argument they are having. I'm glad the writer's made Toph the way they did.  There's enough angsty girl in Katara to last a life time.  Toph reminds me of the earth: it doesn't put up with junk.  It's solid, unchanging.  Katara is one of those girls that takes herself WAY to seriously and just comes across like a queen.  Toph's name is appropriate.

That rant aside, the rest of the story really kicks into gear.  We see Toph meet up with Iroh and the two bond, revealing aspects of each's personality that the two need to see.  Again, the guise Zuko has struggled to keep is coming down and we really get an eyeful of Azula.  Dang, she is so powerful that she can stand against 5 benders + Sokka (yuck yuck) and still survive.  The ending leaves one wanting more and that is all we can hope for in a good story.

It just keeps getting better and better.  Stick around.

Styled after the old Samurai/Western type movies of the past, in this episode we get a much deeper glimpse of Zuko and the anguish he has had to suffer from such a small age.  His story becomes much more complicated as we learn more about this troubled, misguided young man and the changes starting to occur within him.  An obvious "mama's boy" Zuko is tormented by his sociopathic sister and is loved by his over-bearing mother who at some point disappears.  It is obvious Zuko has not come to terms with his mother's disappearance nor of his banishment from the Fire Nation.  This episode could also be called a crossroads for Zuko, for at first he is rising up to move beyond his past, but when he is seriously tempted, he reverts to his old ways, even going so far as to announce himself as the Fire Lord's son to a town.  The villagers call him out on his assertion and it would seem that Zuko is beginning to see that his destiny is not wrapped in his father's.  It is a "sins of the father" type story.

As Zuko begins to put faces to people who have suffered similar fates as his himself and his uncle it begins to dawn on him that his path lies elsewhere.

I have to agree with the other reviewer that the character Toph is a great addition to the show.  She is a rather anti-social little girl, especially considering her over-bearing parents.  Though she's rough around the edges and is quite arrogant, it is not without reason.  This episode shows just the beginning of what Toph is capable of.  I had forgotten her name till I was closing in on this episode and remembered her Season 3 caricature in the fire lord play.  I won't spoil the name, but her reaction is absolutely hilarious!

I liked how they showed Toph's way of "seeing" and that in many ways it reminds me of Daredevil, but not as sucky or Benaffleckish!  However,she does have limitations, as they showed at the end of the episode where Sokka tosses to Toph her belt and it bonks her on the head and knocking her over.  Sokka was on Appa, so Toph's "sight" might not extend to organic matter.  Or just as likely it was a good sight gag!  Heh.  "Sight gag."

No Zucko nor Iroh this episode, but that's okay, we are introduced to the goofy earth bending teacher and promoter that will make their own appearances later, to humorous results.

Keep watching!  This show only gets better!

This was an alright episode.  I think I spent most of the episode smacking my forehead like Sokka due to the annoying hippies.  The other review about the cuteness of the episode is spot on, but I will turn my focus onto Zucko and Iroh

Uncle Iroh is in top form in this episode.  Not really concerned about the state of his existence, he focuses his attentions on finding tea and comes away with a nasty rash due to knowingly choosing to make tea out of something that could be poison (he claims that it might be some great tea.  It's plain to see that Iroh hides behind a cavalier attitude marked by a hedonism that belies something much deeper and worthwhile--regardless, it makes for some good tongue and cheek action).  Unfortunately, we see that Zucko is far from any real repentance as after being given food and good company by some survivors in the Earth Kingdom he repays that kindness by theft.  What was sad was that even Iroh consented to the poor choice.  The look on the survivor girl's face as she watches the two of them steal away (literally) into the night continues to show a world ravaged by greed amongst others.

Most western animation for children is, to put it simply, really wretched. At best, it's tolerable.

But a shining exception would be the tale of the Avatar of all four elements, and to restore the balance in the world. "Avatar The Last Airbender - Book 1 Water, Vol. 1" serves as a solid start to the series -- it smoothly introduces the characters and sets up some nice story arcs, without skimping on development of either.

South Pole Water Tribe siblings Katara and Sokka stumble across a glowing iceberg with a young Airbender boy named Aang (and his flying bison) inside. All Airbenders were killed long ago. You guessed it (and so does Katara): Aang is the Avatar who mysteriously vanished a century ago, even though he has yet to master Earth, Water and Fire. And, uh, he's a total goofball.

Unfortunately, a Fire Nation prince named Zuko has been wandering the world in search of Aang, and agrees to let the Water Tribe alone if Aang surrenders. Of course, Katara and Sokka set out to rescue their friend, and since Katara isn't experienced enough in waterbending to teach Aang, they set out for the North Pole to find a waterbending master.

But along the way they run into new problems -- first Aang returns to his old Temple and finds it in ruins, with all the Airbenders dead. Then the three visit Kyoshi Island, where the female warriors take exception to Sokka's sexism, and Aang starts getting a bit full of himself. Meanwhile, Zuko's quest is put in jeopardy when an arrogant general challenges him to a firebending duel.

The highest compliment I can pay "Avatar: The Last Airbender" is that it's like a thoroughly solid action/fantasy anime. Even though "Book 1, Water: Volume 1" is only the first few episodes of the series, it's pretty obvious that this is not a simple kid's show -- it's got good writing, excellent animation, and a general look rawn from Asian and Inuit cultures.

The first episode is a bit lackluster -- there's a bit too much of Aang goofing around, riding penguins and exploring old battleships, as well as some gross-out humor. But things tart gelling with the explosive fight scenes and grim confrontations of the second episode, especially since we really get to know the Prince Zuko there and get a glimpse of the Fire Nation' power.

And the whole quest-storyline has become nice and tight by the third and fourth episodes, even as our heroes stop for one-off stories. There's plenty of action and explosive fire-battles (particularly Zuko's brilliant battle with the sneering Zhao), but the writers never quite forget to include some comedy (riding the elephant koi) and character development.

And they do a good job with the characters -- Aang soon proves himself a kind and selfless kid, but still a kid. And we get to see some of his inner turmoil when he revisits his old home to find it a snowed-in, abandoned ruin, and his old master Monk Gyatso gone.

Katara and Sokka round out the cast, and are the required bickering siblings -- Katara is short-fused but sensible, and Sokka is rather swelled-headed although it's soon clear that he's courageous and means well. And though he's the antagonist, scarred teenager Zuko is excellent -- his quest obviously has deeper motives behind it, and he clearly isn't a bad person.

"Avatar The Last Airbendeer's" first volume is a fairly smooth introduction to a solid action/fantasy series, and a good setup to an outstanding show. A bit wobbly at first, but it quickly picks up steam.

This is literally the best serialized cartoon made by Americans in the past 10 years.  Michael Dimartino & Bryan Konietzko have created a fantasy world modeled after Asian nations and culture, full of martial arts magic.

Aang is the Avatar, the last of his race (the Airbenders).  As Avatar he is capable of harnessing the four elements that govern their world and keep the peace between the four races (one per element) that populate the world.  Shortly after learning his destiny as Avatar, Aang runs away from the responsiblity.  Near to death after a becoming lost in a seastorm, Aang becomes sealed in ice for a hundred years.

He is set free by Katara and Sokka, who eventually become his traveling companions.  Katara is a young untrained waterbender that is a driving force for Aang's change towards responsibility.  In turn, Aang helps Katara to have more fun.  After a time, Katara becomes his waterbending master.  Sokka is responsible in his own way as well, but ends up as almost comic relief for some of the more emotionally charged scenes.

Additional characters appear and stay with the series.  Prince Zuko is almost a foil for Aang at first before being shown as a more parallel character.  He travels with his Uncle, Iroh.  Zuko's sister and father, Fire Lord Ozai, tend to be the antagonists in the second book.  All are fire nation (the bad guys) but we see in both Zuko and Iroh that that fact does not automatically make them evil heartless killers.

In book two we meet Toph, a blind earthbender girl who doesn't want her family to know that she's a capable bender.  She becomes Aang's earthbending master, and is quite a tough teacher despite her apparent handicap of blindness.

The characters are memorable and well-developed.  The plot line is terrific with many different possiblities of how things could turn out. This is not a cartoon that cops out on sadness or death.  Avatar is not like some of the magical girl cartoons from Japan where people die and then in the next season or episode are right back up and kicking.  Avatar is a better reflection of real life.  When people die (and it's not always bad guys doing the dying) they do not come back. And sometimes the good guys do bad things either because they didn't have all the information or because there didn't seem to be any other alternative.  Hard lessons like truth, justice and good triumphant aren't always learned the first time.

It's really a great cartoon for people of all ages and every stage of life.

I would also like to be put on record as stating that this series is really well written and fun for all ages.  As a 23 year old female, I enjoy watching episodes with my older brother, age 28, and even older male friend, age 38.

The show contains enough seriousness as well as humor to make it fun.  Characters get developed well and new episodes reflect events from past episodes without leaving new audiences in the dark.
My 4 year old only thinks about what Avatar is next!  At night he has to have his Avatar fix.  I also met a lady whose 14 year old son loves it as well.  It is awesome and good messages.

Sifu Kisu is the teacher and shows you the basic techniques or principles behind the four bending arts also known as Airbending (BaGua), Waterbending (Tai Chi), Earthbending (Hung Gar), and my personal favorite firebending (Northern Shaolin).  He even gives some moves.  The only problem with these special features, is that most of it is an introduction, which you see over and over again, with a different background setting for each element. The moves that Sifu Kisu does are small moves, which leave the viewer wanting to see more of the realistic martial arts.  There could have been more with that, I believe. As great a show as Avatar is, it deserves much better treatment in the DVD release.

There are 5-6 advertisements at the start of the DVD that have to be skipped over one by one to get to the show.  Hint to DVD developers: If you want to put adds on a DVD, put them in the main menu and not at the start of the DVD.  The former will draw people in, while the latter just feels like an imposition.

There are very few extras and they are very short. (Less than 5 minutes total.)  They are moderately interesting, but should have been much better.  There are also no chapter breaks within the episodes.  It would have been good enough just to place chapter breaks where the commercial breaks would have been instead of one chapter per episode.

This may not be the fault of the DVD, but the episodes are all in 4:3 instead of 16:9.  If a 16:9 version is available then it should have gone on the DVD.  If not, then the show's producers need to check the year on their calendars.

Paying over $3 for each half-hour episode is bad enough, but could be excused if at least some thought was put into releasing a decent DVD.

Even if you never watch animated shows, I reccomend checking this one out because it is really different than most "cartoons."  Everything is drawn in a realistic style and I get the impression that they would have made it a live action show if it weren't for the fact that all the incredible special effects would have been prohibitively expensive to pull off that way.

So try watching this show (preferably from the beginning).  The DVDs are worth it.

Yes, I'm going to join the chorus praising the series.  It's stylish, the art and character designs are high-quality, and each episode holds up well for multiple viewings.  There's drama, suspense, more action than you can throw a stick at, and plenty of humor to ease the way.  The core characters are well-rounded, and they grow as the first season progresses.  We get backstory slowly, woven into the story.  We keep learning about the characters.

While I, too, would have preferred a series set over single-disk releases, I can't pretend to be surprised.  I buy a lot of anime, and Japanese series are released one disk at a time.  Maybe a complete set comes out sometime after the regular releases are done, with a nice box.  Anime fans pay a premium for their fix - $20-$30 for 3-5 episodes, $80-$200 for a series/season box set.  While this is Nickelodeon, not a US-license of a Japanese series, let's face it:  Avatar isn't Spongebob.  This show isn't like anything else on Nick.  The production values are much higher, and the production costs increase proportionally.  A $40 season set isn't likely any time soon.

There is a rumor that a box set with unknown bonus features will be released AFTER the single disks are all out.  Again, this is typical practice for anime releases, not a nefarious Nickelodeon plot.  Those who are disappointed or peeved should contact Nickelodeon to ask about a set.  Let them know they've failed to meet your expectations.  If you refuse to buy the series piecemeal - tell them why.  If they don't get feedback, they're not going to reconsider their release strategy.

This series is well worth owning on DVD.  The question is whether you want to treat yourself to a disk every couple-three months, or wait and see what is offered in a year or so.  There's no wrong answer here... but buy it sooner or later.  It is that good.
